content: When mathlib4 port is finished, will lean 4 be just as good at theorem proving as lean, maybe even better?
What does "good at theorem proving" mean to you?

Patrick Stevens said:

What does "good at theorem proving" mean to you?

All the capabilities

crab said:

All the capabilities

Do you mean everything that Lean 3 currently supports? I haven't heard of anything that will be dropped.
The kernel does not support stuff like homotopy type theory anymore iirc?
But that is the only thing I know
This HoTT change is from the Lean 2 to Lean 3 transition
J. O. has marked this topic as resolved.

there are some new things in lean 4 that didn't have lean 3 equivalents, e.g. a pattern match-defined function will now only have as many cases as there are in the source code. That said, many tactics come from mathlib not from lean itself, those (once re-implemented for lean 4) should make proofs just as convenient as before.

Some new things will make things better going forward, too.

Another new feature is structural recursion for inductively defined predicates.
